Influenza virus evolutionary dynamics are another theorised driver of influenza virus epidemiology. Within each type and subtype of seasonal influenza virus, new major antigenic variants arise every 3â€“8 years
14, 15 . New variants partially escape the immunity induced by prior infections and vaccinations, rendering a higher fraction of individuals susceptible to infection. Epidemiological theory predicts that epidemics caused by a new antigenic variant should therefore be larger than epidemics of previously circulated variants
16, 17 .
